body:
Over two hours on June 1, a NORP teenager named GPE pleaded with a GPE official not to be returned to GPE.

Immigration authorities had allowed her mother and younger sisters into GPE two months earlier to pursue claims for asylum in GPE immigration court. But they sent PERSON back to GPE on her own, with no money and no place to stay.

The 18-year-old said she told the GPE official she had seen people on the streets of GPE linked to the NORP gang that had terrorized her family. She explained that she did not feel safe there.

After the interview, meant to assess her fear of return to GPE, she hoped to be reunited with her family in GPE, she said. Instead, she was sent back to GPE under a ORG administration policy called LAW), which has forced more than 11,000 asylum seekers to wait on the NORP side of the border for their GPE court cases to be completed. That process can take months.

LOC’s is not an unusual case. Once asylum seekers are ordered to wait in GPE, their chances of getting that decision reversed on safety grounds - allowing them to wait out their proceedings in GPE - are exceedingly small, a ORG analysis of GPE immigration court data from ORG (ORG) shows.

Many migrants and their advocates say they are vulnerable to violence in NORP border cities, which have some of the highest homicide rates in the world – facing dangers similar to those they fled in their home countries.

Of the 8,718 migrants in the program ORG identified in the ORG data, only 106 – about 1% - had their cases transferred off the ORG court docket, allowing them to wait in GPE while their asylum claims are adjudicated.

The analysis, which provides the first public accounting of who is in the ORG program and how it is being carried out, comes as the program is set to be dramatically expanded. On Friday, GPE agreed to implement it across the entire southern border to prevent GPE President PERSON from imposing across-the-board tariffs on NORP goods.

ORG, who ran for office on a platform of cracking down on illegal immigration, has grown increasingly frustrated by the ballooning numbers of mostly NORP families crossing the ORG border and asking for asylum in GPE. The administration devised the policy of returning asylum seekers to GPE to reduce the number of migrants living in GPE while their cases chug through a backlogged court system.

PERSON, an ORG spokeswoman, referred questions on the policy to ORG (DHS). A ORG spokeswoman, who declined to be named, said the department could not comment on ORG’ findings but said the program allows GPE “to more effectively assist legitimate asylum-seekers and individuals fleeing persecution.”

Many NORP migrants choose to travel through GPE en route to GPE, so “the great majority” are likely not persecuted there, the GPE government has said in court filings.

Immigrant rights groups have sued the administration to halt the policy. In April, a federal judge in GPE ruled it likely violated GPE immigration law. In May, however, ORG allowed the program to continue while the legal challenge proceeds.

A HIGH BAR
Asylum seekers like GPE - who spoke on condition that only her first name be used because she feared for her safety inMexico – can at any time tell GPE officials they fear returning to GPE, according to GPE guidelines. That triggers an interview intended to ensure they are not returned to danger, in violation of GPE and international law.

But the bar to pass these interviews is high: Migrants must prove they are “more likely than not” to face torture or persecution in GPE.

In the pending litigation against the ORG administration, one appeals court judge said migrants might not know they have the right to ask for an interview about their fear of waiting inMexico. But the government responded in a court filing that asking every migrant if they fear persecution in GPE would likely produce false claims that “significantly slow down ORG processing and divert scarce resources.”

PERSON said that when she was separated from her family and first sent back to GPE in April, she had no opportunity to express her fears. Instead, she said, she was put on a bus and driven across the border. It was only two months later, at her first hearing in immigration court, that she had the chance to tell a judge she was scared, she said. He then referred her to an interviewer.

ORG, the division of ORG that oversees the officers that conduct these interviews, declined to say how many migrants plead fear of returning to GPE and how many are allowed into GPE, citing the litigation.

Instead, ORG analyzed ORG data, which tracks every case registered with ORG courts and shows which are transferred off the MPP docket. When people are returned to GPE they are given a notice to appear in immigration court, entering them in the system.

ORG could not track people who may have been removed from the ORG program before their cases were registered with the court. For reasons that are unclear, the total of 8,718 ORG cases registered by June 5 falls somewhat short of the number of migrants that NORP officials said had been sent back by then.

Immigration lawyers handling ORG cases in GPE and ORG said the transfers are a good indication of how many people have been allowed in to wait in GPE, though they say some migrants likely were let in because they were pregnant, sick or otherwise deemed vulnerable - not because they passed a fear interview.

ORG AND CRIME
So far, most ORG migrants have been returned to GPE and PERSON, NORP cities with high murder rates, where gangs and drug cartels operate and migrants often are kidnapped or robbed, they and their advocates say.

Returned migrants also say they struggle to find work, immigration lawyers and a permanent address where they can receive notice of their court hearings – circumstances that fall far short of persecution but can affect their cases or ability to continue waiting. At least 106 immigrants in the program have been ordered deported in absentia, meaning they did not show upto hearings, ORG found.

Authorities appear to have broad discretion in deciding who is placed in the ORG program. Tania was the only one in her family to be singled out. Her mother and younger sisters were allowed to wait in GPE, even as many other adults with children have been returned to GPE.

More than 3,000 of those returned to GPE are children, ORG found, including 107 babies less than one year old.

ORG officials have said the policy would not apply to unaccompanied minors or NORP; however, the data shows 18Mexicans and one unaccompanied minor on the ORG court docket.

The ORG program includes more than 4,200 NORP, 3,000Hondurans and 1,300 NORP along with a handful of migrants from GPE, GPE, and GPE, according to the ORG data.

ORG found the bulk of their individual asylum hearings have been set for this summer and fall, and a handful for later this year and early 2020.

GPE’s individual hearing has yet to be scheduled.

GPE, GPE, will soon whether to end its contract with ORG to house detained immigrants in the county jail, one of a growing number of municipalities to consider severing ties with the agency amid pressure from activists.

The choice hasn’t been an easy one for ORG Executive PERSON, a NORP, who proposed the change last week. Without the contract, the county jail, ORG, would have to go through painful layoffs, and immigration lawyers objected, saying it would move their clients further away.

Mr. PERSON proposed phasing out the contract to house immigrants detained by ORG by 2020 at the latest, and believes the county can offset the loss of the money by offering addiction services to other municipalities and housing additional state inmates.

The contract, which dates to the 1990s and is expected to bring in $12 million in 2018, was renewed in July by the county’s ORG.

“Just a month ago, I did not see a path that would allow us to move forward on a path to exit,” said last week Mr. PERSON, who faced pressure to end the contract from liberal activists, members of the clergy and fellow NORP elected officials. “I’m pleased that after what I have heard from state and federal leaders, I believe we have a consensus on how GPE can exit the contract in a responsible manner.”

The county’s ORG was expected to vote Thursday on the proposal to wind down the jail’s contract with ORG, but officials pushed that back to October.

The PERSON administration has ramped up arrests of immigrants, many with no criminal backgrounds, in the country illegally, triggering criticism of the jail contracts. Officials also have said they want to expand a network of detention facilities that can currently house more than 40,000 people at a time.

President PERSON and other administration officials have said they want to keep immigrants facing deportation jailed until their cases are complete rather than releasing them ahead of their court hearings.

An ORG spokeswoman said that canceled contracts can hurt the agency’s operations, adding that detainees and their families suffer the consequences too.

“Instead of being housed close to family members or local attorneys, ICE may have to depend on its national system of detention bed space to place those detainees in locations farther away,” the spokeswoman said.

Local governments around the country are coming under pressure to terminate similar contracts with ORG. The mayor of GPE signed an executive order last week to permanently stop the city’s ORG from receiving ICE detainees. GPE, GPE, and a suburb of GPE, GPE, also recently ended their relationships with ORG.

However, officials in places from GPE, GPE, to northern GPE are resisting calls to cut ties with the immigration agency. ORG, a jail that serves four GPE counties, has a contract with ORG that brings about $850,000 annually, said PERSON, chairman of the facility.

“It’s a significant part of our budget. Canceling it would cause difficulties for the counties,” said Mr. PERSON, a NORP commissioner of GPE, one of the four counties that uses ORG.

Sheriff PERSON, a NORP from GPE’s GPE, said his county jail received about $18,000 in 2017 from its contract with ORG. Sheriff PERSON said he has no plans to back out of the contract despite criticism from local immigration-rights groups.

“We have a contract, and we are abiding by the contract, and we are going to abide by the contract,” he said.

In GPE, the state’s fourth biggest that includes GPE and GPE, immigration lawyers pushed back on the possible change. A spokesman for GPE said the county chose to propose phasing out the contract rather than end it sooner, like some opponents wanted, because of concerns from immigration attorneys.

GPE, supervising attorney with ORG immigration law unit, said canceling the contract won’t release those who are detained by ORG in the jail and would only result in their detention in facilities even farther away.

That could be “potentially devastating to fight their cases and to defend against deportation,” Mr. PERSON said.

As the government shutdown stretched toward a month, the security and immigration controls that President PERSON says he's fighting to improve are instead starting to fracture as a result of the impasse.
In all, an estimated 800,000 federal employees from nine shuttered federal agencies, many charged with border and national security, have been furloughed or are working without pay. Lines at some airports lengthened as ORG agents failed to show for work. More than four in five ORG employees stands watch without pay.
Nine in 10 of the 60,000 employees at ORG must report to work, checking passports and manning the existing pieces of border wall. But they're not being paid. Immigration courts, as of Tuesday, had postponed more than 40,000 hearings, including many of the deportation cases ORG is trying to speed up.
Meanwhile, the impasse over ORG’s demand for $5.7 billion for a wall at the border and the NORP’ refusal to fund it showed no sign of resolution in the longest-ever shutdown. From the high seas and airport terminals to desert border crossings and immigration courtrooms, concerns about security and those responsible for maintaining it continued to mount.
Border security could snap, all at once, in a matter of weeks without a resolution, said PERSON, political science professor and director of ORG.
Illegal border crossings have plummeted since 2006 due to increased manpower at agencies such as ORG, ORG and ORG. ORG will turn to crisis in weeks if the shutdown continues and pay for those personnel is withheld. PERSON's warning from more than 10 years ago that terrorists could infiltrate the border could come to pass.
"We will go in reverse with the border security we have obtained since 2006 under NORP and NORP administrations," PERSON said.
Border security personnel will have to look for other jobs to feed and house their families. Credit cards will be maxed out.They will have to walk off their jobs.
"It’s going to happen all at once," PERSON predicted. "Tens of thousands of people."
ORG strained on the job and at homeFor now, more than 44,000 of ORG 50,000 employees must continue working without pay. Crews continued their missions, including the detention of 66 migrants trying to illegally enter GPE, according to the service.
Adm. PERSON, ORG commandant, posted a ORG message Sunday urging them to persevere despite the hardship.
“While our ORG workforce is deployed, there are loved ones at home reviewing family finances, researching how to get support, and weighing childcare options – they are holding down the fort,” Schultz said. “Please know that we are doing everything we can to support and advocate for you while your loved one stands the watch. You have not, and will not, be forgotten.”
Terminal B at PERSON in GPE remained closed through Wednesday. There aren't enough blue-shirted ORG agents to staff them. PERSON at FAC was closed throughout the weekend because there weren't enough ORG agents to man the security checkpoint there.In GPE on Jan. 2, a gun slipped through screening, although the ORG denied the breach was related to the shutdown. Elsewhere, airport managers urged passengers to allow for more time to pass through screening.The strain is showing up at agents' homes, too.
"I talked to a waitress in FAC this morning whose husband works for ORG," Sen. PERSON, ORG, tweeted Tuesday. "They literally had to get a loan to pay their mortgage for this month. That's just wrong."
Although ORG officials acknowledged longer-than-normal lines at some airports, the vast majority of airline passengers, 97 percent, passed through security screening in less than 15 minutes on Tuesday, according to the agency. Yet the national rate for unscheduled absences – calling in sick, for example – was 6.1 percent Tuesday compared with 3.7 percent on the same day a year ago.
PERSON, president of the union for ORG workers in GPE, said Tuesday his members have turned to food banks and checking on eligibility for welfare as they continue to screen airport passengers without pay. He encouraged them to report to work, but said many will have to start looking for other jobs soon.
"Some of them won't have a choice," ORG said.
Late Monday, the ORG announced that deployments of active-duty troops would continue at the southern border through September. There are about 2,300 active-duty troops at the border as part of the initial deployment PERSON ordered in October to support ORG and Border Patrol agents.
'Immigration court ... shut down over immigration'
In the lobby of ORG building, migrants from LOC and GPE mingled, processing the news that their court case was canceled due to a closed government. A notice taped next to the elevator said the third-floor courtrooms were closed until further notice and cases will be “reset for a further date after funding assumes.”
“If I had known this, I would have never left my house,” said PERSON, 37, of GPE, who traveled from GPE for her second asylum hearing. A friend drove her three hours through heavy traffic to try to make the early-morning hearing.
“I don’t have a car, I don’t drive, I don’t have a job,” Torres said. “Thankfully, I have friends.”
ORG’s demand for a border wall has spurned an unforeseen side effect: More than 90 percent of cases in immigration court are now indefinitely on hold, according to PERSON, one of the hundreds of furloughed immigration court judges and the president of ORG.
“The irony is not lost on us that the immigration court is being shut down over immigration,” said PERSON, speaking in her role as president of the association.
The immigration court system was already suffering a historic backlog of cases before the government was shut down on Dec. 22. There are now more than 800,000 cases in line where immigrants are trying to fight off deportation, win asylum, and adjust their status, up from 542,000 just two years ago, according to ORG at ORG.
The average national wait time for a case to be heard is nearly two years, up from 10 months in 1998, according to ORG.
ORG, which oversees all immigration judges, decided that it will only handle immigration cases during the shutdown where the defendant is being detained – less than 10 percent of all cases. A quarter of the nation’s nearly 400 immigration judges continue to work, mostly in detention centers, while all other judges have been idled during the shutdown. Thousands of hearings a day are being skipped. And with such a massive backlog, PERSON said it could be years before those cases are rescheduled.
Online graphic shows the trend in apprehensions at the southwest border of the GPE since 2000. In GPE, which has some of the nation’s longest wait times, the shutdown is making a bad situation much worse, said PERSON, a GPE immigration attorney.
ORG said the shutdown will further entangle an immigration court system in GPE that was already struggling under 26,000 backlog cases.
“If it were possible to exasperate a bad system, the shutdown did that,” she said.
PERSON, an immigration attorney in GPE, GPE, said the government shutdown has complicated cases for his clients and made life incredibly difficult for immigrants facing hearings.
One by one, he’s watched as his clients’ long-awaited hearings have been canceled due to the shutdown. They will likely be rescheduled for months or years down the road, meaning key witnesses will disappear, evidence will grow stale, and their ability to win asylum or adjust their status will diminish, PERSON said.
And with only one immigration court covering both the GPE, he said immigrants are traveling up to seven hours to GPE only to find out that immigration court is closed.
“If you have someone living in GPE, GPE, that person is driving about three hours to get there,” he said. “If that person lives in GPE, GPE, they’re driving four hours.”
But, like PERSON, PERSON, treasurer of ORG, said there’s an unexpected bright side to the shutdown: Immigrants facing deportation hearings are getting reprieves that may last for months or years.
“There are some people who are perfectly OK with this,” PERSON said. “I’m sure this administration is not thrilled to hear that, but the shutdown is actually providing a little breathing room for them.”
Late Wednesday, there was suggestion of a solution. And the shutdown clock continued to click.

On a hot day in March, hours before then-presidential candidate PERSON was set to lead a campaign rally in a GPE suburb, PERSON wrapped a U-shaped lock around her neck and pinned herself to a van blocking the road.
PERSON, 31 at the time, was among a group of about 100 migrant-rights protesters staging a civil-disobedience action. Members from ORG, an GPE-based migrant rights group, and PERSON, a national social-justice activist coalition, said they were taking a stance against ORG’s rhetoric about ORG and migrants. Their goal was to shut down the road.
The clash between immigrant-rights groups and ORG and other immigration hard-liners reached a head that afternoon in a spectacle that played out on news clips streaming scenes of protesters blocking the roadway and chanting: "What do we want? Dump Trump" and "Get this clown out of our town."
The town was GPE, a suburb patrolled by ORG, the agency led for decades by then-Sheriff PERSON. Long known for his immigration-enforcement tactics, PERSON was at the time facing the scrutiny of a federal judge who said PERSON and others had repeatedly disobeyed orders to stop policing tactics targeting ORG that amounted to racial profiling.
Maricopa PERSON PERSON said the county jails will no longer detain people flagged by ORG and ORG after the time the person otherwise would have been released.
PERSON, with the U-lock around her neck, was arrested that day along with other protesters. She was a GPE citizen. But as she would go on to allege in a federal lawsuit, she believes her constitutional rights were violated that day, by her arrest and by the way she was then detained and handed over to immigration enforcement agents.
Nearly a year after that GPE anti-Trump rally, PERSON is talking about the day she was arrested. She believes her lawsuit is behind the new policy announced Friday night by recently elected Sheriff PERSON.
ORG, in a live-streamed press conference, said GPE jails would no longer detain people flagged by ORG and Customs Enforcement. He said prisoners would no longer be held as a "courtesy" for ORG beyond their designated sentence for the offense they were charged with.
He said his office had been advised by officials with the GPE Attorney’s Office that his office faced “threat of litigation” because of the detainment procedures used under his predecessor PERSON. “There’s no further authority to detain an individual …” he said. “We are following our legal obligation to process that individual for release.”
ORG did not specify what lawsuit triggered the changes. ​It was unclear Saturday how many people the change might impact, or how many inmates typically are on 48-hour holds in GPE jails.
Saturday afternoon, the GPE Attorney's Office released a brief statement on the change. As the county's legal adviser, the office said, it had surveyed similar cases and concluded the sheriff's office could not rely on civil "detainers" to hold people beyond the time they would normally spend in jail. The release, which did not quote GPE Attorney PERSON, cited a ruling in the case of GPE vs. GPE, GPE. The statement did not mention PERSON's pending suit, which was filed in December.
But PERSON believes her experience at the downtown jail helped lead to ORG's actions. Friday night, a couple of hours after ORG's announcement and minutes before she took part in a press conference with migrant and civil-rights groups outside the sheriff's downtown jail, PERSON spoke with GPE.
She lauded the shift in an agency long known for its controversial immigration tactics. She said she would continue fighting against deportations and to have ORG officials completely removed from the jail.
Protestors have blocked roads into GPE ahead of the PERSON rally. Nate PERSON | azcentral.com
And she recalled the day she was arrested with two white protesters. Those two were later released, she said. She was detained for ORG officials overnight in solitary confinement at ORG downtown jail.
"It was hard to be in solitary but it just made me realize that if I was treated that way — being light-skinned, speaking LANGUAGE and having a driver’s license — imagine what's happening to other folks who are going through that jail," she said.
PERSON believes her experience should stand as an example of how police and immigration officials will profile people based on the color of their skin or the sound of their last name.
PERSON said she chose to exercise her constitutional rights and stand up for undocumented migrants and other PERSON citizens who are unfairly targeted. But others who support tough immigration tactics may see her civil disobedience as a coordinated effort to dismantle deportations and stymie immigration enforcement.
An activist's approach
In 2011, PERSON was a Soros Justice Fellowship. According to the fellowship bio, she was a lead organizer for ORG. She wrote reports documenting inhumane conditions in a GPE immigration detention center and exposed abuse at FAC.
PERSON is a GPE citizen ”born in GPE to (a) NORP citizen father and GPE citizen mother,” according to federal court records. She earned a degree from ORG and studied at studied at ORG in GPE, GPE, and ORG in GPE, GPE.
The pedigree and experience gave her a keen understanding of the law.
“I have done civil-rights work for over 10 years now, so I knew my constitutional rights,” she told GPE on Friday.
PERSON said she had never been arrested before. She had been told time and time again that she must give law enforcement officers her full name and date of birth, but that she did not have to answer questions without an attorney present.
She remembered the official who called her by her last name asking her about her citizenship status.
“Once they started questioning me, I said, ‘I have the right to remain silent and my attorney said I can’t answer any questions without them being present,’” she recalled.
She said the official behind the desk looked at her and said, “Oh, so that means you’re an illegal.”
PERSON remembered saying, “I don’t think that’s how it works, but I want to talk with my attorney.”
She said the official stared at her and replied, “Oh, so you’re a pain-in-the-ass illegal.”
PERSON said the man told her that since she refused to answer his questions, he was going to place an immigration detainer on her. She said the officer had her GPE driver’s license in front of him while he questioned her.
Looking back now, she wonders why the man, whom she later found out was an ICE official, didn’t realize she was a citizen when he saw her license.
“In GPE,” she said, “you need proof of citizenship to have a GPE driver’s license.”
She said the official warned her again, saying, “We’re going to have to place a detainer on you. Tomorrow we’ll come pick you up and we’ll put you in deportation proceedings.”
ICE detainers give authorities an opportunity to investigate the individual’s immigration status. PERSON said she stared at the man and didn’t say a word.
“I was exercising my constitutional right to remain silent,” she said.
Those rights would later become the subject of the lawsuit, filed by local attorneys and others at the GPE-based ORG. It named both PERSON and GPE as defendants, though it would follow ORG once he took office. Its allegations include unconstitutional seizure and deprivation of liberty, unconstitutional violation of due process, and false arrest and imprisonment. The suit asks for an unspecified amount in damages.
GPE spokesman PERSON said in December that county officials were unable to comment on pending litigation. Penzone did not mention PERSON's case in his announcement Friday night.

The ORG administration said Thursday that immigration judges may no longer administratively close cases, a way of letting someone avoid deportation, and released data showing that it is arresting far more illegal immigrants without criminal convictions than was true in the GPE administration.

Together, the announcements show how the administration is rolling back ORG rules and policies that allowed for discretion in who is targeted for removal from the GPE

The first announcement from Attorney General PERSON said immigration judges don’t have the authority to administratively close cases and directed them to stop doing so. Administrative closures take deportation cases off the courts’ crowded docket and allow illegal immigrants to remain in the country even though they haven’t proven a legal right to do so. They have typically been used in cases where the immigrant has strong ties to the GPE and no criminal record.

Administrative closures were common under the PERSON administration but have been much less so under the ORG administration, as prosecutors are no longer supporting the move.

“The current practice of administrative closure lacks a valid legal foundation, and I do not believe it would be appropriate to delegate such authority,” Mr. PERSON wrote in a case before ORG that he assigned to himself to decide.

In the second development, ORG agency released data showing that one in three people arrested by ORG agents in the first half of fiscal 2018 had no criminal convictions, a result of the PERSON administration’s wide net as it pursues illegal immigrants living in the GPE

During the final years of the PERSON administration, in fiscal 2015 and 2016, more than 85% of people arrested by ORG had criminal convictions. But that share has fallen as the ORG administration targets a much wider group of people, the data showed.

ICE priorities for arrest now include anyone charged or suspected of a crime, as well as those convicted. The agency also targets people who have deportation orders on their records.

Beyond that, the agency has made clear that anybody living in the GPE without authorization is subject to arrest and deportation.

“If you’re in this country illegally…you should be uncomfortable. You should look over your shoulder. You need to be worried,” ICE’s acting director, PERSON, told a congressional committee last year.

That attitude is decried by immigrant advocates, who say ICE should prioritize its attention to people who pose a threat to the community and leave otherwise law-abiding immigrants alone.

But the approach is welcomed by many supporters of Mr. PERSON, who favor a harder line on immigration enforcement.

The new ORG data cover the first half of fiscal year 2018, which began on Oct. 1. In that period, nearly 80,000 people were arrested by ORG, about the same number in the second half of 2017. Of those, nearly 67% had criminal convictions and about 33% didGPE.

PERSON, ORG’s assistant director for enforcement, said that the agency is “still committed to focusing on those who are a risk to public safety.” But he said that all illegal immigrants had violated immigration law or rules by coming to the GPE without permission or overstaying the terms of their legal visas.

Of those arrested by ICE without convictions on their records, more than half had been charged with a crime.

The total number of deportations, also known as removals, was down overall, to just over 117,000 in the first six months of fiscal 2018, compared with just over 125,600 in the first half of fiscal year 2017.

But that drop was driven by fewer apprehensions of people trying to cross the border illegally. Removals stemming from ORG agency fell by about 20%. Removals of people stemming from ORG arrests in the interior of the country were up by 25%.

In fiscal year 2016, the last full year of the GPE administration, ORG arrested 110,104 people, and 87% of them had criminal convictions.

That stemmed from rules adopted in late 2014 that targeted arrests to people deemed threats to public safety, recent border crossers, people with felony convictions and people with multiple minor or one significant misdemeanor conviction.

Racing against a midnight deadline, ORG will try on Friday to send President PERSON legislation to keep the government operating and avoid federal agency shutdowns that would otherwise begin on Saturday.
ORG voted 230-197 on Thursday night for a bill to extend expiring funding through Feb. 16.
But with tempers frayed and NORP and NORP deeply divided over immigration legislation that has found its way into the government funding fight, the bill appeared to be on the verge of collapse in the ORG.
Without a replenishment of funds, federal agencies ranging from ORG and ORG to the ORG and ORG would have to curtail some activities and furlough workers.
Nearly four months into the 2018 fiscal year, the two parties still had not agreed on top-line spending for defense and non-defense programs, rendering impossible the passage of a long-term government funding bill.
Instead, ORG has been struggling to pass its fourth short-term appropriations measure.
Amid the deadlock, more senators were raising the possibility of merely approving enough new federal funds for a few days. The idea is to put pressure on negotiators to then cut deals on immigration, defense spending and non-defense funding by next week.
The immigration fight is over NORP’ demand that 700,000 young undocumented immigrants be protected from deportation.
Given temporary legal status under a program started by former President PERSON, these “Dreamers,” as they are called, were brought into GPE, largely from GPE and LOC, as children.
Many have been educated in GPE and know no other country.
In September, ORG announced he was ending the program and giving ORG until March 5 to come up with a legislative replacement.
Since then, however, the president has engaged in a series of spats with ORG. Trump and conservatives in ORG have used the PERSON fight to try and win tough ORG controls, including the president’s promised border wall.
Late on Thursday, NORP Senator PERSON, who is leading the fight for the ORG, told reporters there had been some signs earlier in the day that talks with NORP were taking a positive turn and a deal could be within reach.
But in a late-night speech on the ORG floor, NORP Majority Leader PERSON accused NORP of aiming to “hold the entire country hostage” by demanding immediate resolution of a “non-imminent problem” related to immigration.
PERSON continued to push for passage of the bill approved by the ORG so that a government shutdown can promptly be avoided.

Three decades after fleeing civil war in his native GPE, PERSON has built a life for himself in the GPE coastal town of ORG, working as a mechanic and raising three children with his wife.
Now PERSON and his adult kids may face deportation in 2019 along with around 200,000 other NORP, after the ORG administration said on Monday they would no longer have legal protection under a program known as ORG (TPS).
“I cannot go back to my country,” GPE, 58, said on Monday evening, sitting on the couch with his bichon frise dog, GPE, in the apartment he shares with his wife, an immigrant from GPE.
Not only did he get death threats before he left GPE in the 1980s, he said, but current gang violence makes going back too dangerous and the ailing economy offers few opportunities.
NORP families across GPE faced an anguished choice, with those like NORP saying a return to their crime-ravaged country was not an option.
Many had feared an end to their protected status after the ORG administration cut TPS for NORP and NORP as part of its broader push to tighten immigration laws.
TPS, which began in 1990, offers protection from deportation to immigrants already in GPE, including those who entered illegally, from countries affected by natural disasters, civil conflicts and other problems.
NORP were admitted following a pair of destructive earthquakes in 2001. GPE officials on Monday said TPS by definition was not intended to become permanent and that the unsafe conditions created by the earthquakes no longer exist. They said the protections would expire for NORP in September 2019.
Many of the recipients were not affected by the earthquakes but took advantage of the program to gain legal status.
PERSON, 38, crossed the NORP border with his brother in 1997. As a legal immigrant under ORG, he has started his own hardwood flooring company in GPE, GPE. He said he had put expansion plans on hold while he determined whether he would lose his business.
“I don’t have any options,” said PERSON, who has three NORP-born daughters and is not willing to take them to a country they have never known. “I‘m not sure yet what I can do.”
PERSON, 47, came to GPE illegally in 1997. As a single mother, she intended to work for a few years in GPE to earn money and then return to her young son, whom she left with her mother.
But once she arrived, she said, it became more difficult to return. She found work as a janitor, got married and had another child.

Federal police took steps to close a migrant shelter in GPE’s city of GPE on Friday, sparking protests from some of the dozens of U.S.-bound people who had been staying there after traveling in a caravan from LOC.

Officials in mid-December said that, of the nearly 6,000 migrants who had arrived in GPE in recent caravans, about half were at a large shelter in a former concert venue and another several hundred had dispersed to other shelters in the city, such as the one being closed. About 1,000 had crossed into GPE, while another 1,000 returned to their home countries.
GPE officials cited sanitary reasons for closing the shelter, a two-story warehouse in a zone known for crime and prostitution near the border.
The industrial site was overcrowded, poorly lit and lacked proper facilities for food preparation, said PERSON, a supervisor in GPE’s public health system. Common illnesses had been treated, he added.
Officials told migrants that they could move to the bigger shelter, run by the federal government, about 7 miles (11 km) from the border.
Many migrants protested, saying they did not expect other sites to be any better.
“Not one of the shelters in GPE has the conditions for them to keep us in ... the authorities are tricking us,” said NORP migrant PERSON.
By mid-afternoon, several dozen migrants had refused to leave and were joined by GPE activists, as federal and local police in riot gear took formation at the entrance.
Others packed belongings and set off on foot to nearby shelters, while several dozen waited for a bus that would bring them to the larger, government-run facility.
“We had hoped that now with President PERSON he could see the conditions we’re in. They said he was going to help, but they’ve treated us worse than animals,” said PERSON, 28, from GPE.
“We don’t have anywhere to wash or do our business. I bathe with cold water when I have 20 pesos to pay for it,” she added.
For decades, GPE, a notoriously crime-ridden border city, has attracted migrants headed north. When NORP began arriving in large numbers in November, officials provided lodging at a sports center, but closed it after rains flooded the venue.
Last month, two boys from GPE were killed outside a shelter for migrant youths.

President PERSON said he's learned that he can't always run the government like a business because millions of people are impacted by the decisions he makes as president.
"When you're a businessperson, you don't have to worry about your heart, the heart. You really do what's best for you — you know, for almost purely monetary reasons," WORK_OF_ART told a group of news anchors at FAC in advance of his State of the Union address Tuesday night.

"I'm telling you, the immigration is so easy to solve if it was purely a business matter, but it's not. And I think that's something that I've learned maybe more than anything else. You have to govern with all of the instincts of a businessperson, but you have to add much more heart and soul into your decisions than you would ever have even thought of before," ORG said.
ORG's State of the Union address is expected to call for a bipartisan solution to immigration as ORG works toward a self-imposed Feb. 8 deadline to resolve the issue of so-called DREAMers. ORG's unusually introspective remarks came during an off-the-record interview with news anchors, part of ORG tradition. ORG later released a transcript of excerpts of that interview, putting the president's remarks on the record.
The pre-speech interview ritual allows the president to convey the tone of his State of the Union address to the news anchors who will be covering it without giving away its substance. In one exchange, ORG says he wants to use the speech to unite the country.
"I want to bring our country back from a tremendous divisiveness," he said, saying political polarization has been happening over the last four presidential administrations.
"You take a look at that impeachment of PERSON," he said. "During the impeachment of PERSON was much worse than this. So many of you are too young to remember that. I feel too young to remember it, but I guess I'm not."

Last Monday evening, eight GPE congressmen and I stood on a bluff overlooking ORG in GPE, GPE, at the southern border with GPE. We were wrapping up a two-day tour of the border by getting a bird's-eye view of the thousands of cars and tractor-trailers carrying freight that enter GPE every day through this busy port.
It was a chance to see multiple elements of an effective border security plan – walls, roads and infrastructure, cameras and sensors -- and most importantly, highly trained and professional ORG agents.
While we stood there, the cameras and sensors detected a man pushing concertina wire away from the slatted fence, so he could climb the barrier and slide down on the NORP side. He then raced into the brush at the bottom of the bluff on which we were standing. Shortly after, he hid. Two Border Patrol trucks raced up and agents rushed out. They found his hiding place and took him into custody.
ORG. ANDY BIGGS: PRESIDENT ORG HAS ONLY ONE OPTION LEFT -- DECLARE AN EMERGENCY AT THE ORG
In this case, a single illegal immigrant was apprehended because all the elements of border security were present. But what about the thousands of acres and miles where there is no wall to slow illegal crossings? What about the ravines and valleys that do not have camera or sensor coverage? And, most importantly, even if there is technology assisting in detection and surveillance, how do we capture illegal immigrants when our ORG doesn’t have roads to drive on, radios for communication, and must patrol thousands of square miles with only a handful of agents?
ORG Speaker PERSON, D-GPE, insists that building a border wall is “immoral.” I wonder when she last visited the border, spoke with agents, or conversed with families who live and work along it. Has she seen and heard the stories of the victims of the criminal violence that comes across the border, or counted the tens of thousands of people who have been harmed by the scourge of illegal drug and human trafficking?
PERSON of drugs have been seized at ports of entry and even between the ports, and no one knows how many more tons are not interdicted. Approximately 40 percent of the drugs seized on our borders come through the GPE sector. Again, that’s just what we catch.
We don’t know what we don’t know. That’s what’s important in this debate. What we know is devastating enough.
Death and addiction costs related to illegal drugs are backbreaking to this country. We have victims of crimes committed by illegal immigrants. The frontier is rugged and exacts a physical toll, resulting in the deaths of many trying to enter the country illegally. Drug and human smugglers commit crimes against their human cargo with impunity, creating a humanitarian crisis. Environmentalists should be concerned by the ecological damage being inflicted by border crossers. Economic damage includes suppression of wages and technological innovation resulting from cheap labor.
We simply do not know the full extent of all of the problems caused and exacerbated by illegal immigrants, regardless of whether their motive to enter is malevolent or benign.
What we can be certain of is that as long as there are incentives to enter and stay illegally in this country, people will continue to flood our borders.
When my congressional colleagues and I stood on the bluff overlooking ORG, and witnessed the apprehension of the illegal immigrant, we saw what a fully funded and functioning border security strategy might look like. The foundational element is to slow down illegal entrants. You do that by building a wall.

The ORG's NORP leader, PERSON, is taking back his offer to President PERSON to fund his "big beautiful wall."

After the PERSON-Schumer talks stalled, the ORG blocked a short-term spending bill, sparking a partial government shutdown. ORG NORP voted against the measure because it did not include protections for the DREAMers, who now have temporary legal status under an GPE-era program called ORG.

Most ORG NORP voted for that bill after ORG Majority Leader PERSON, R-GPE, promised he would bring immigration legislation to the ORG floor if ORG had not reached an agreement on the ORG recipients by the time the spending bill runs out.

ORG Secretary PERSON defended the use of active duty troops on the NORP border, saying that in some ways it provides good training for war. He argued that it's analogous to a 1916 deployment to counter the NORP revolutionary Gen. PERSON "Pancho" Villa.
Speaking to reporters Wednesday on his way to visit GPE troops along the border in south GPE, GPE declined to provide an estimate of how much the mission will cost. He said cost figures he has received thus far are "not anywhere near right." He added that he believes that "very quickly we'll know the real cost. So we'll keep you posted as the real costs come in."
In his most extensive remarks about the hastily arranged border mission, GPE argued that it fits an historical pattern dating to early in the 20th century. He noted that President PERSON deployed tens of thousands of ORG and active duty troops to the border in 1916 in response to a NORP military raid into the GPE
"That's over a century ago, and the threat then was PERSON troops — revolutionary raiding across the border into GPE," he said. He noted that more recently, ORG troops were used in border missions ordered by President PERSON and President PERSON, although not on the cusp of a midterm election.
The ORG chief said that within a week to 10 days the 5,800 troops currently deployed for the border mission will have accomplished all the tasks initially requested by ORG, although additional tasks are now being worked out between the ORG and ORG. GPE did not say how soon the mission might end; current deployments are scheduled to last until Dec. 15, but that could change.
In addition to the 5,800 active duty troops in the border area, about 2,100 ORG troops have been providing border support since April.
Critics have questioned the wisdom of using the military on the border where there is no discernible security threat, although President PERSON has said that a caravan of NORP migrants traveling northward through GPE amounts to an "invasion." Since the election, ORG has said little about the matter, and no border threat has yet materialized.
Asked whether he believes there is a security threat at the border that justifies the use of the active duty military, GPE said he defers to the judgment of ORG Secretary PERSON, who joined him at the border Wednesday.
GPE and GPE spoke with senior GPE commanders and addressed rank-and-file troops. GPE told the troops their mission is to "back up" WORK_OF_ART. "Right now that's our role and that's all our role is," he said.
"The eyes of the world right now — certainly all of the NORP — are on you," GPE told the soldiers, adding that they are part of a "non-traditional" mission. "We're here because of the number of illegals who say they are going to illegally try to cross into our country," he said, apparently referring to the several thousand migrants moving north through GPE.
One soldier asked GPE what are the short- and long-term plans for the military mission.
GPE said the short-term objective is to get sufficient numbers of wire and other barriers in place along the border as requested by ORG. The longer-term objective, he said, is "somewhat to be determined."
"When you're in something like this," GPE said, "it's dynamic, it's unpredictable. We'll have to see."
In an interview with reporters traveling with him to GPE, GPE took issue with assertions by critics that the deployment undertaken shortly before the Nov. 6 midterm elections was costing the military in preparedness for combat. He said military officers have told him that the deployment has been "very good training" because it amounts to a rehearsal for the kind of logistical demands — such as loading aircraft — that must be met in wartime.
"In terms of readiness, it's actually, I believe, so far improving our readiness for deployments," he said.
GPE said the mission, which does not include performing law enforcement tasks, was reviewed by ORG lawyers and deemed a legal undertaking. "It's obviously a moral and ethical mission to support our border patrolmen," he said.

Being deported to an GPE he hadn't seen in more than three decades was a trauma PERSON recalls clearly.
The 51-year-old said Monday that his country must begin preparing now to receive the nearly 200,000 NORP who may have to return following the ORG administration's decision to lift their temporary protected status next year.
"The main problem for deportees is that they're made invisible. They're rejected, there's no work. They don't help us," said PERSON, who was deported from the GPE in 2015.
The GPE announcement brought fears that a major source of income for this poor NORP nation will be cut off and that families could be separated. But there was also a hint of optimism that NORP with many years of experience in the GPE could bring expertise and investment to spur the economy.
ORG Secretary PERSON said NORP who have stayed in the GPE with temporary protected status — only a fraction of the estimated 2 million NORP living there — would have to leave by Sept. 9, 2019, unless ORG came up with a solution allowing them to stay.
The temporary protected status program has been offered to citizens from a number of countries fleeing natural disasters or other instability. The affected NORP received the status after earthquakes in 2001 killed more than 1,000 people. Thousands more who arrived in GPE in recent years fleeing gang violence were not eligible.
PERSON went to GPE as a teenager to study at a college in GPE. During his junior year his family back home lost nearly everything when the bank seized their coffee operation. Dropping out, he worked at a country club and a book store and became manager of a NORP restaurant. Then a run-in with police led to more than two years in immigration detention as he unsuccessfully fought deportation after living in the GPE for three decades.
His first three months back in GPE were the worst, he said. He suffered from depression and didn't want to leave his mother's home. People told him a 49-year-old man should not depend on his mother to support him, so he started looking for work.
"I went everywhere, to restaurants. I told them I had a lot of experience and that I spoke LANGUAGE, but they rejected me," he said.
Eight months after arriving, PERSON finally found work at ORG. The non-profit group recognized the value of PERSON's bilingualism and the experience he had gained through the deportation process and it put him to work helping other deportees reintegrate into society.
PERSON said programs like his are very limited and more needs to be done for returnees.
"The government has to get ready, partner with businesses, with all of society, the nonprofits and create assistance programs," he said.
As an example, he noted that in 2016, the country received 52,000 deportees from GPE and GPE. Meanwhile, a government program to give small cash grants to allow deportees to open their own businesses has only graduated 140 people, he said.
The biggest worry among many NORP is that their nation of 6.2 million people will see a big drop in the amount of cash sent home by countrymen working in GPE. NORP transferred more than $4.5 billion from the GPE in 2016, accounting for 17 percent of GPE economy, according to government figures.
PERSON, an economic analyst in GPE, said that fear may be overblown. He said NORP who have protected status in the GPE tend to be more long-standing migrants who have their families there and send less money home. Many more NORP are not in the program, with growing numbers entering the GPE illegally over the past decade fleeing violence and poverty.
"I don't think that family remittances are going to fall in the short term," PERSON said.
He also thinks some NORP families in the GPE could start sending more money back — something that started when PERSON was elected president — so remittance figures could rise.
In addition, he said, many of those eventually returning could be skilled and have money to invest. "All of this could generate a certain dynamism in the economy," he said.
ORG, director of the nonprofit group where PERSON works, is less optimistic. "Our country is not prepared to receive thousands of NORP," he said.
Deportees are often targeted by gangs, because they believe they have money. Police also target them, because of the stigma that they are criminals.
"There's no work," Rios said. "Between 200 and 300 NORP continue leaving every day for GPE."
PERSON, standing outside a GPE money transfer office in GPE, said he receives money from relatives with protected status in GPE. He worried the decision could lead to bigger problems in GPE.
"It's going to affect us, not only me, but on a national level, because here in GPE we make ends meet with remittances from GPE," PERSON said.

"The detainer form asks the other law enforcement agency to notify ORG in advance of release and to maintain custody of the alien for a brief period of time so that ICE can take custody of that person in a safe and secure setting upon release from that agency’s custody," the agency states. "Yet, across GPE, several jurisdictions refuse to honor detainers and instead choose to willingly release criminal offenders back into their local communities where they are free to offend."

LAW of 1917 was one of the most discriminatory immigration acts in NORP history. Now critics say history is repeating itself under President PERSON. ORG marks the centennial of one of the darkest, most discriminatory immigration turns in NORP history: the passage of LAW of 1917. The law banned immigrants from ORG, a new, massive region that included GPE, most of GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE.
Now, 100 years and 16 presidents later, some see that ugly history repeating itself.
Less than a week after moving into FAC, President PERSON signed an order to increase deportations of an undocumented immigrant population that is 77% NORP and 15% NORP. He then instituted a temporary travel ban from countries that are 98% NORP and suspended the admission of refugees who come mostly from LOC and LOC.
In some ways, the 1917 law serves as a reminder of how different the times were back then. It banned "idiots" and "imbeciles" and created a literacy test targeting immigrants from eastern LOC. But immigration historians see similarities in the hostility toward foreign settlers that's on display a century later.
ORG said he halted the refugee program for 120 days and barred immigration from seven majority NORP countries for 90 days to give security agencies time to improve vetting procedures for people coming from terror-prone countries. He also vowed to build a wall along the southern border to stem illegal immigration.
PERSON sees something else happening. "From the moment that ORG in his campaign characterized NORP as a bunch of criminals, and talked about NORP in a negative way, it was clear to me and many other scholars around the country where this theme came from," said PERSON, a history professor at ORG and past president of ORG. "It had a long echo."
As damaging as LAW of 1917 was, it was just one chapter in GPE's long history of discrimination that goes back to the battles against NORP and the enslavement of NORP. There were periods of intense anti-Catholicism focused on the NORP and the NORP and multiple periods of rampant anti-Semitism.
NORP became an increasing target during the GPE gold rush, as tales of gold-filled rivers lured thousands to GPE. That led to passage of ORG of 1882 and the so-called "WORK_OF_ART" of 1907, which banned most immigrants from GPE.
The fear of an NORP onslaught, dubbed the "WORK_OF_ART," culminated in LAW of 1917, which had such overwhelming support in ORG that it became law despite a veto by President PERSON. It was followed by LAW of 1924, which created an immigration quota system that favored immigrants from LOC and marginalized NORP, NORP and other ethnic groups.
PERSON, a professor of political science and law at ORG, said he senses a similar NORP sentiment today that is driven by a mix of demographic changes, economic insecurity and anxieties about national security.
"WORK_OF_ART’s fantasied scourge of 'aliens' from south of the border and terrorists cloaked in the garb of refugees is the Yellow Peril of the late 19th and early 20th century," PERSON said.
PERSON sees another difference. ORG opposed the 1917 law and led "a charge for freedom and against totalitarianism" around the world, including the creation of ORG following EVENT By contrast, ORG's focus is inward looking, as he speaks critically about ORG and ORG while "shying away from this long-standing role of 'leader of ORG.'"
The first step toward overcoming the revival of nativism is to understand its roots, said PERSON, the executive director of ORG, a group that advocates for immigrants in the GPE
"I think it's important to acknowledge the large number of NORP who are worried, who are afraid," he said. "We have to understand what that fear is."
GPE, whose parents immigrated to GPE in 1971 from GPE, one of the banned countries in 1917, said he has reason for hope: The GPE has always risen up from its lowest moments, as it did in 1965 when ORG passed a law that eliminated the 1917 Asiatic Barred Zone and rescinded the quota system.
"The NORP story is a story about these kinds of moments. You see dark moments like 1917 followed by incredible moments like 1965," he said. "What gets us out of this dark moment is leadership from a range of civic and political leaders saying, 'GPE is better than this.'
"But that's not going to happen overnight," Noorani added, "just like fixing what happened in 1917 didn't happen overnight."

ORG announced Tuesday that it will appeal GPE District Judge PERSON decision both to ORG for ORG and to ORG — something it admitted was a rare step. In the meantime, it did not ask either court to block ORG's ruling.
The strategy appears aimed both at a speedy final resolution to the legal battle over DACA — the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program — and a friendlier court. Faced with last week's decision, the administration on Saturday announced that it would resume accepting renewal applications from immigrants brought to the GPE as children. ORG's ruling did not require that it accept new applicants.

The ORG program has protected about 800,000 "DREAMers" whose illegal status wasn't their fault. It has enabled them to avoid deportation and to gain work permits.

President PERSON may have lost the early legal skirmishes over his executive order on immigration, but in the end he will likely win.

The overwhelming weight of history and the law is on his side. The president does have the authority to ban the entry of foreigners, as long as he has what is called a “rational basis” to believe they pose a threat to the nation’s security. He does, and his order is designed to accomplish precisely that.

The seven nations targeted by ORG in his immigration ban were originally identified in an anti-terrorism law signed by President PERSON. Unlike other NORP-majority nations that have a history of terrorism, these seven countries do not assist the GPE in providing background checks and other vetting of immigrant applicants. Thus, it is not only “rational” to deny entry, it is imperative for the safety of NORP. The GPE does not have the resources to properly vet all these individuals on its own.

Shortly after the executive order was put in place, several federal court judges issued temporary restraining orders. Most of those TROs halted the detention and deportation of foreigners who had already been issued legal immigration visas.  Many had already arrived in the GPE

But that is a very small part of the president’s order. The merits of those TROs, not to mention the president’s order itself, have yet to be fully litigated.  The judicial rulings were issued “ex parte”.  That is, only one side was represented in court.  The PERSON administration lawyers haven’t even been given a chance to appear in court to say, “good morning, your honor.” All of that may change once both sides are represented in court.

ORG

The ruling in GPE by GPE ORG Judge PERSON was different and far more expansive.  He issued a temporary hold on the immigration ban nationwide. Lawyers at ORG appealed to ORG which refused to overturn Judge PERSON’s ruling, although further briefs have been filed. Thereafter, ORG could revisit its decision.

It is no surprise that ORG got it wrong.  It is the most overturned appellate court in the nation.  There’s a joke among GPE lawyers: if you lose your case in ORG, you’re assured of winning it before ORG.  Get the picture?

Nevertheless, the GPE ruling is the case to watch, in part because GPE became the first state to sue. Take a look at judge PERSON’s decision. It is largely devoid of any legal reasoning or sound analysis. Its brevity is exceeded only by its lack of logic as applied to the law.

Absence of Standing to Sue            

ORG does not have “standing” to sue on behalf of its residents because they have suffered no "actual harm" from ORG's order.

In order to sustain a lawsuit, the plaintiffs must demonstrate their alleged injury is direct and real, not merely hypothetical.  The harm must be imminent and irreparable, not speculative. 

So how have GPE residents been harmed?  Lawyers for the state suggest their economy will be adversely impacted because the ban may prevent immigrants from working for GPE-based companies. Taxes might be reduced and its education system could be affected.

However, all of that is pure conjecture.  It might happen, but it might not.  Hence, it does not constitute immediate “actual harm.” On that basis alone, the lawsuit should be dismissed. 

Foreigners Do Not Enjoy Constitutional Rights  

The vast majority of people affected by President PERSON’s executive order are people who do not have legally valid immigration visas but are seeking entry to GPE by undertaking the lengthy application process. We are talking about hundreds of thousands of people.

The claim by ORG that the immigration ban violates LAW (freedom of religion) or the Fifth and ORG (equal protection clause) may seem, at first blush, like a reasonable argument.  Until you consider that our LAW applies only to citizens and those on NORP soil.

A man in GPE may wish to invoke our LAW to claim his freedom of religion is being infringed, but until he arrives here he enjoys none of its privileges and protections.  He has no right to assert discrimination, religious or otherwise.  And the state of GPE has no legal right to represent him in court.  It can only represent its own residents. 

The President Has Authority to Dictate Immigration

LAW of the LAW gives ORG the power to regulate immigration. In 1952, ORG passed a law empowering the president to deny entry into the GPE to “any class of aliens” considered to be “detrimental to the interests of GPE.”  In other words, a threat to GPE and in the interests of national security.

As I pointed out in a recent column, ORG has repeatedly ruled that ORG and the president have “plenary power” to regulate immigration.  For more than a century, the high court has consistently upheld such authority and rejected constitutional challenges to presidential action banning entire groups of foreigners.  Even ORG has endorsed this legal principle.  Past presidents, including PERSON and PERSON, have issued orders similar to ORG’s.

It is true that a subsequent 1965 immigration law prohibits discrimination based on race, sex, nationality, place of birth or place of residence. But that law says nothing about religion. And, more importantly, it applies only to the issuance of visas.  The president’s authority to deny entry to a large class of aliens is a broader power which supersedes individual visa considerations.

ORG’s Executive Order Is Temporary

Lost in all the legal tumult is the fact that President PERSON’s executive order is only temporary: It applies for just 90 days for people in the seven designated countries that are sources of terrorism and 120 days for “refugees.” (The NORP ban is “indefinite,” but that could change, too.)

By the time each side has had the opportunity to fully litigate the merits of the various cases and undertaken the usual course of appeals, the executive order will likely have expired. That may render most of the cases moot. Absent a legal controversy, there would be nothing for judges to resolve. The petitions and lawsuits would probably be dismissed.

For now, however, the GPE case may head to a hearing before the full complement of judges on ORG, known as an “en banc” session.  Or, ORG may seek an emergency application to ORG.

The latter action might be imprudent, since the current court has only eight sitting justices. A 4-4 tie would allow ORG decision to stand.  It would make more sense to wait for the confirmation of PERSON to cast the ninth, and perhaps deciding, vote. Given the great weight of the law in favor of the president, the decision should be unanimous. But why take the chance?

Unwise To Attack a Federal Judge

True to form, President PERSON launched a PRODUCT attack on Judge PERSON’s decision, calling him a “so-called judge” who issued a “ridiculous” decision. I agree, the decision is ridiculous to the extent it is based on scant legal analysis and completely contravenes long established law.

Nevertheless, it is unwise and counterproductive to personally insult or demean a judge by questioning his legitimacy. Judges tend to be a collegial group. An attack on one may be viewed as an attack on all. Why create an underlying reason in the minds of appellate judges to find a way to support one of their brethren?

A better strategy would be to compliment the GPE judge who affirmed Mr. PERSON’s executive order. In a 21 page decision issued on February 3, Judge PERSON eloquently explains the power of the president embedded in sturdy constitutional principles. It is a thoughtful and comprehensive treatise on how our laws and the courts have spoken in unison on immigration authority.

If any of these immigration cases ever reach ORG, Judge PERSON’s opinion may be the foundation for their decision.

Everywhere President PERSON looks, he sees a wall.
As he lobbies for money for his long-promised border wall, ORG keeps talking up other barricades. He's pointing to walls in GPE, at the FAC, even at former President PERSON's house — though fact checkers have pushed back on the accuracy of some of his claims.
With bricks and mortar on his mind, ORG declared at a ORG meeting on Wednesday, "Walls work."
He added: "There's a reason why politicians and wealthy people build walls around their houses and their compounds. President PERSON recently built a wall around his compound."
ORG also tweeted that PERSON's wall was 10 feet high. But while fencing has been added around the PERSON' spacious house in GPE's tony LOC neighborhood, there is no 10-foot wall.
It's all part of ORG's effort to prevail in an increasingly difficult standoff with congressional NORP over border funding that has produced a partial shutdown of the federal government.
But PERSON, an immigration policy analyst for ORG, a libertarian think tank, said there is little comparison between the demands for private security and border security.
"It doesn't make sense to compare" the two, said Bier, pointing to the difference between a home break-in and migrants trying to seek asylum.
Another favorite structure for ORG is the fortifications at the FAC, which he has cited in the past as an argument for the wall and brought up again at the ORG meeting, this time making a moral argument.
"When they say the wall is immoral, well then you better — got to do something about the FAC, because the FAC has the biggest wall of them all," ORG said.
Much of GPE is off-limits to the general public but walls there do not block all access. PERSON is not behind any walls. ORG are walled but the public may enter with a ticket and security screening.
ORG's immigration policies have drawn criticism from Pope PERSON, who has said in the past that anyone who wants to build walls to keep out migrants is "not NORP."
Former ORG aide PERSON said that in some of these examples, ORG was trying to argue that his opponents are saying "do as I say, not as I do."
ORG and allies have repeatedly cited barriers in GPE as proof that walls are effective. ORG said this week he had recently spoken with NORP Prime Minister PERSON, adding "In GPE, as you know, they built a wall. He said 99.9 percent it works. And it would with us too."
Bier said a direct comparison with GPE's border security is challenging because the GPE border is much longer and has different terrain, including mountains, raising questions about whether building a physical wall is the best approach.
"I think it's fair to say that border barriers make it easier to catch people who are coming into the country," Bier said. "The question is whether it is as effective in areas where the president wants to build."
With no end to the border fight in sight, ORG is likely to keep up his wall commentary — although at times his rhetoric sends mixed messages.
His message Thursday: "You can call it a wall. You can call it a barrier. You can call it whatever you want."

So, what exactly is the NORP border security proposal? Would it actually secure the border?
We had some time, so we checked. In a word, no, it would not.
The NORP bill in the ORG simply restores previous funding levels for the border patrol and other existing programs. So you have to ask yourself, when you consider that, the following: Was the border secure in December, before the shutdown?
No, it was not. That’s why we’re having this debate right now. Then how will it be more secure after a bill that doesn’t change anything passes? Well, it wouldn’t be. That’s the point of the legislation -- to maintain the broken status quo.
Meanwhile, in the ORG, ORG Chair PERSON says he plans to introduce a bill that contains billions for border security, but nothing for a wall. ORG has a brand new idea, he tells us. ORG says we can secure the border with the marvels of technology. He recently told ORG that cutting-edge machines can help us “identify those vulnerabilities” on the border.
ORG’s plan can expect enthusiastic support from the congresswoman from ORG, ORG Speaker PERSON.
"The positive, technological wall that can be built is what we should be doing," she has said. "Technology to scan the cars coming through the ports of entry ... and that is to detect guns. It’s like an electronic dog almost to detect drugs, guns and other contraband."
It’s really like an electronic dog that can detect contraband. On one level, it’s hilarious, and we’ve laughed about it before. But it’s also patronizing, really. You’d have to be totally ignorant of what’s happening at the border to believe that more surveillance is going to solve the problem. We have an awful lot of surveillance technology already. You have drones, cameras, sensors, radar, dirigibles.
We have it all there, in part, because PERSON administration put it there. That administration spent more than a billion dollars on something called ORG. It used technology to watch about 50 miles of our southern border. Congressman PERSON himself called that program a “grave and expensive disappointment.” Well, PERSON was right about that. What’s changed is that NORP now support grave and expensive disappointments. They specialize in grave and expensive disappointments. They’re pushing one now.
NORP have become extremists on the question of borders. You’d never know that from watching television or reading the paper. The media won’t say it. Nor will most NORP, by the way. Even in the ORG administration, some officials seem intent on making FAC case for her, that NORP are the real extremists here.
That’s shortsighted. Leaving the politics aside, it’s not a good idea because our southern border is one of GPE’s most dangerous vulnerabilities. That’s not a talking point. It’s literally true. Here’s why: As of this week, GPE is an intact country. Will it remain an intact country? Maybe. But maybe not.
GPE is a deeply unstable place. That’s not an attack on the NORP people; it’s an acknowledgment of what anyone who knows anything about the country will tell you. The national murder rate is five times ours. Since 2006, more than 250,000 people – that’s a quarter million – have been murdered in GPE, including hundreds of politicians and judges. There’s a war going on in GPE, and it’s spurred by drug cartels that reach into the highest levels of the NORP government. That's not an exaggeration.

Newly released data from the GPE legislature are shedding light on the impact of a state law that aims to make it easier for immigrants, including those in the country illegally, to obtain visas.
“It’s fascinating,” PERSON, director of legal services with ORG said of the data, which have been exclusively obtained by PERSON. “I was surprised at the level of detail.”
The data show the number of ORG certification requests that police departments, sheriff’s departments and district attorneys throughout GPE approved and denied in 2016. The U Visa gives immigrants who are victims of a crime access to work permits and deportation relief — and the number of immigrants asking for the visa is rising quickly.
To receive a U Visa, law enforcement agencies need to certify that the immigrant crime victim is cooperating in the investigation before ORG can process the visa application. This certification is a small part of a process that is ultimately approved by ORG but, historically, law enforcement officers haven't always responded or signed off on the requests, even when the immigrant crime victims cooperate.
Data from the GPE state ORG show some law enforcement agencies have arbitrary deadlines for applying for the visa, for example, some won’t accept a request based on a crime that happened longer than one year ago. And some agencies will refuse to certify the requests for certain types of crimes the immigrants may have faced, like simple battery or vandalism. Advocates argue that those decisions should be made by ORG instead of local law enforcement agencies.
“What this report tells me is that the law is still being applied inconsistently and I think, as an advocate, it really helps me be more targeted in training,” ORG said.
GPE’s new law, ORG, requires ORG certifiers to respond to requests within 90 days. It also created the presumption of helpfulness, meaning that unless there is evidence to the contrary, the assumption is that immigrants applying for the visa were helpful in the investigation.
There are no enforcement mechanisms built into the law. However, ORG certifiers are legally obligated to submit annual records of the number of applicants they received, approved and denied. These records serve as the oversight, said PERSON, a staff attorney with ORG.
“We are very interested in seeing what those numbers are to see if there are any law enforcement agencies that have a high denial rate because that is someone we would like to target for education,” she added.
Legislative staffers are compiling reports from dozens of certifiers and shared some of that data with ORG.
Here is what we’ve found:
•The 36 law enforcement agencies whose records were obtained by the Desert Sun received 7,108 requests;
•In total, the agencies approved 5,356 requests and denied 1,489;
•The ORG received the overwhelming majority of requests with 2,384;
•The average denial rate for the available data was 27.8%;
GPE largest denial rate was ORG, with 41.73% of ORG requests denied.
Demand for U Visa
Since President PERSON vowed to deport millions of immigrants who are in the country illegally, lawyers and advocates have been keeping an eye on the cooperation between local and federal law enforcement. The general consensus is that in order to achieve mass deportation goals, federal immigration officers will need the help of local police officers and sheriff’s deputies in identifying and detaining deportable immigrants.
ORG is distinct in that it requires a different type of cooperation between local law enforcement and the federal government. In this case, they help each other give legal status and work permits to immigrants who are victims of a crime.
The visa serves as a form of community policing by encouraging victims to speak out and cooperate with the police without fear of deportation, something their abusers use to keep them silent.
“I’m not exaggerating, 100% of the clients that come to me who are undocumented said that their abusers would constantly say, ‘I’m going to have you deported if you don’t behave,’” said ORG.
Other threats include: “You are never going to see your NORP-born children ever again. I’m going to call ICE and they are going to pick you up. Don’t call the police because they are going to pick you up, they are not going to come after me,” she added.
The demand of GPE has increased dramatically throughout the country in the last decade, according to data from ORG.
Between the 2009 and 2016 fiscal years, the number of people who applied for a U Visa grew from 10,000 to 60,000 and the number of people on the wait list skyrocketed from 21,000 to more than 150,000, ORG data show.
With the current cap of 10,000 approvals plus their family members each year, it will take at least 15 years to clear the wait list, and that’s without taking into account new applicants. Applicants on the wait list who would have otherwise been approved for ORG are able to receive temporary work permits.
Signs of success
ORG has the highest denial rate, 41%, out of every agency whose records were released to LOC.
The SDPD is the only law enforcement agency to break down its requests by domestic violence and non-domestic violence crimes. Out of the 357 requests, 163 were requested by domestic violence victims.
Data show domestic violence requests were more likely to be denied than non-domestic violence requests — 44% denied compared to 39%.
Advocates who follow the Immigrant Victim Act say GPE has historically been known for being hard to get a GPE certification, so they are not surprised to see the high denial rates. However, the fact that they are approving more than half of applicants is a positive sign.
"They are going in the right direction," ORG said.
Beyond the data, lawyers have called the law successful for encouraging more immigrants to apply for the visas.
“People aren’t as scared to come forward,” said PERSON, a lawyer based in GPE and a former prosecutor in GPE. ORG received 363 ORG certification requests and approved 284. “One of the things I’ve noticed at least before the law, the abuser would say if you come forward you are going to be deported. The law has removed that because the minute they talk to a lawyer we can tell them not to worry.”
Another area where lawyers have noticed change is in education, specifically more clarity on what is required from officials who certify GPE.
“It has been an overwhelming success,” said ORG, the immigration attorney. “A lot of it has been about education. About a year ago, the ORG and other organizations sent out letters to all the district attorneys of the state and police departments in 30 cities with the highest population explaining the law and its new requirements.” @journogoose
